facts.text: Petitioner carries on business as a broker in diamonds and precious stones in Calcutta and enjoys credit and reputation in the market as a well-known and respectable broker.

On May 4, 1955, Rummaging Inspector Intelligence, Customs House, Calcutta (Respondent No. 3), armed with a search warrant from Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta (Respondent No. 4), searched petitioner's residential room at No. 32, Sir Hariram Goenka Street, Calcutta.
Search of steel almirah where petitioner kept stock in trade found nothing; petitioner denied having diamonds.
Wall almirah containing washed clothes and other articles searched; 475 pieces of diamonds and one piece of synthetic stone discovered in an old jacket.

Statement signed by petitioner: Rs. 10,000 worth of diamonds received from Messrs. Ratilal Amritlal of 89 Zaveri Bazar, Bombay; rest purchased locally in Calcutta; did not remember names/addresses of local sellers; no documents corroborating purchase.
Petitioner escorted to Customs House; Assistant Collector asked for evidence that goods were not smuggled but legally imported on payment of duty and valid licence; permitted to go till May 7, 1955.

Notice served on petitioner on May 4, 1955: reasonable grounds to believe goods illegally imported; submit documents by May 7 showing legal import or purchase evidence; references to ss. 167(8) and 167(39) Sea Customs Act.

May 7, 1955: Messrs. S. K. Sawday & Company (advocates) wrote to Assistant Collector alleging unwarranted presumption under s. 86 and s. 167(39); requested statement of reasons for seizure and 10 days for certificates from Bombay/Calcutta trade.
May 16, 1955: Letter enclosing two certificates, further particulars, reiterated request for reasons.
May 23, 1955: Assistant Collector replied: diamonds seized on reasonable suspicion of illegal import, liable under Sea Customs Act.
June 20, 1955: Letter from petitioner side; June 25 reply detailed prior denial, discovery in jacket, justification for proceedings; warned of decision on record if no explanation.
July 1, 4, 20, 1955: Further letters from K. Sawday Company objecting.
July 22, 1955: Letter from advocates with statement from Messrs. Ratilal Amritlal.

September 12, 1955 (dispatched November 5, 1955): Collector of Customs order confiscating diamonds under ss. 167(8), 167(39) Sea Customs Act and ss. 3(2), 4 Imports & Exports Control Act, 1947; petitioner failed to discharge onus under s. 178A; reasons: contradictory statements, attempt to hide, afterthoughts; appeal to Central Board of Revenue within 3 months.
Petitioner approached Supreme Court under Art. 32 without availing appeal remedy.

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 178-A, inserted in Sea Customs Act, 1878 by s. 14 of Amending Act XXI of 1955, is unconstitutional as offending Art. 14 of the Constitution.
Whether provisions violate Art. 19(1)(f), (g) and Art. 31 (faintly argued).

petitioner_arguments.text: s. 178-A offends Art. 14 by giving unrestricted arbitrary power to customs authorities without standard; inverts burden of proof contrary to natural justice; heavy onerous burden on innocent possessor/purchaser to prove not smuggled.
Faint contention of violation of Arts. 19(1)(f),(g) and 31.

respondent_arguments.text: Seizure on reasonable belief of smuggling; petitioner failed to rebut presumption under s. 178-A; contradictory statements, suspicious hiding.
Section based on reasonable classification of easily smuggable goods; rational nexus to prevent smuggling; rebuttable presumption.

court_reasoning.text: s. 178-A casts burden on person from whose possession seized goods (gold, diamonds etc.) taken in reasonable belief they are smuggled; applies to specified easily smuggable goods seized under Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Heavy burden even on innocent possessor, but prerequisite is subjective reasonable belief of officer.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 14 permits reasonable classification founded on intelligible differentia with rational relation to object; here classification of specified smuggable goods seized on reasonable belief has nexus to prevent smuggling.
Act provides safeguards: search warrants by Magistrate on Collector's application, adjudication by superior officers, appeals to Chief authority/Central Govt.
Enacted per Taxation Enquiry Commission recommendation to transfer onus in smuggling cases.

holdings.text: s. 178-A does not offend Art. 14; valid reasonable classification with rational nexus to prevent smuggling.

statutes_cited.relevance: Governs importation, searches, seizures, presumptions, confiscations, penalties, appeals in smuggling cases; s.178A shifts burden for specified goods.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.14 equal protection; challenged on grounds of discrimination; Art.32 for writ petition.

outcome.summary: The Court held s. 178-A constitutional, not violative of Art. 14 due to reasonable classification of smuggable goods with rational nexus to prevent smuggling; petition under Art. 32 dismissed as petitioner bypassed appeal remedy.

key_quotes.text: "Where any goods to which this section applies are seized under this Act in the reasonable belief that they are smuggled goods, the burden of proving that they are not smuggled goods shall be on the person from whose possession the goods were seized."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Art. 14 forbids class legislation... but does not forbid reasonable classification... founded on an intelligible differential... rational relation to the object."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test from Budhan Chaudhury applied to uphold section.

key_quotes.text: The impugned section cannot be struck down on the infirmity either of discrimination or illegal classification.
key_quotes.speaker: court
